--- title: Predictive decisioning 300-level live demo description: Predictive decisioning 300-level live demo tabs: [ 'Demo preparation', 'Demo script'] --- export const Title = () => ( Predictive decisioning
300-level live demo ); ![banner](./images/proactive-incident-resolution-300-script-github-banner.jpg)
Introduction
Thank you for attending this Predictive Decisioning demonstration.

Today I’ll show you how IBM Cloud Pak for Business Automation uses machine learning to enhance Retention offers. You will learn how to integrate Watson Studio Machine Learning with the Cloud Pak to create prediction services. These predictions are then used by automated decision services to target retention policies, lower customer retention costs, and eliminate many paper-based processes.

We will see how business users can quickly get started creating and using predictions to improve their everyday processes. Data scientists will also learn ways to speed experimentation in AI development.

Let’s get started!

**[Go to top](#top)**
1 - Reviewing the manual call center process
| **1.1** | **Show SkyTalk’s current manual process** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | SkyTalk is a telecommunications provider losing many of its best customers to competitors. SkyTalk needs to reduce customer churn. Let’s review the set of written customer retention policy guidelines department management implemented. | | **Action**   1.1.1** | Show SkyTalk’s **Retention offer document** opened during demo preparation. Discuss the problems caused by the current manual process.

| | **Narration** | Call-center agents were asked to understand various retention offers and pick the ‘best’ option to retain the client. There were several problems with this approach. did not work well because of the variety of reasons.

Agent could not factor in unique customer circumstances, and thus offers were not tailored. SkyTalk’s retention policy guidelines were implemented inconsistently by call center agents. Agents also needed to make real-time decisions while on the phone with the customer, adding time pressure.

The results were skyrocketing customer retention costs, while attrition remained steady.

SkyTalk needed is a reliable way to find the lowest cost retention offers that customer at risk of leaving would accept. SkyTalk decided to invest in an automated predictive solution.

This new application will leverage decision automation and machine learning to provide agents customer-specific retention offers in real-time. Machine learning will be used to analyze a customer profile to guide the decision automation in the retention offer selection. Let’s start and see how to automate the retention offer determination using business rules. | **[Go to top](#top)**
2 - Modeling the business rules
| **2.1** | **Review the components of SkyTalk’s retention decisions** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | A business analyst in the customer care division uses machine learning and decision automation technologies to configure the retention offer application.

The business analyst writes a set of business rules to generate retention offer recommendations. This set of rules is called a decision service and is shown on a decision model diagram. | | **Action**   2.1.1 | Access the Business Automation Studio on the IBM Automation home page window opened during demo preparation. Then click **SkyTalk customer retention DS.**

| | **Action**   2.1.2 | Click **Open**.

| | **Action**   2.1.3 | Click **SkyTalk Initial retention DS**.

**Note:** DS stands for Decision Service.

| | **Action**   2.1.4 | Click **Retention offer**.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst creates an automated decision, called a decision service, using a hierarchical model of business rules. Each blue box represents a sub decision. The green shapes represent the input data.

The ‘Determine retention offer’ decision service requires two inputs: ‘Ranked retention offers’ and ‘Retention budget’ sub decisions that both use predictions.

The ‘Ranked retention offers’ sub decision establishes a list of eligible offers for individual customers and calculates the cost of retention.

The ‘Retention budget’ sub decision calculates SkyTalk’s maximum cost that should be spent to keep the customer. The retention budget is calculated using predictions for a customer’s lifetime value and propensity to churn.

The ‘Ranked retention offers’ top-level decision cycles through the list of eligible offers and selects the least expensive one that does not exceed the calculated retention budget for the given customer.

Now the business analyst uses IBM Watson Studio to create the two predictions required by the ‘Retention budget’ sub decision. | | **Action**   2.1.5 | Review the **Retention offer decision model** after it opens.

| **[Go to top](#top)**
3 - Creating the predictive models
| **3.1** | **Show data sources used for prediction** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The business analyst started a project to create machine learning models and deploy them for use in SkyTalk’s execution environment. | | **Action**   3.1.1 | Click **SkyTalk customer retention project** in the Watson Studio project window opened during demo preparation.

| | **Action**   3.1.2 | Click the **Assets** tab. | | **Narration** | Five years of data from SkyTalk’s existing customer database has been loaded into IBM Watson Studio. The analyst uses this data to develop predictions for customer lifetime value and churn.

| | **Action**   3.1.3 | Open the **SkyTalk customer loyalty data.csv** file.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst reviews the historical data file uploaded in IBM Watson Studio to make sure it contains the data required to predict customer churn.

The T (true) in the CHURN column indicates that a customer closed their SkyTalk account. The F (false) indicates they are still SkyTalk customers.

Watson Studio automatically generates prediction models that estimate the significance of the other parameters in predicting whether customers may churn. Generating the models is referred to as an “experiment.” | | **Action**   3.1.4 | Review the displayed **SkyTalk customerloyaltydata.csv** file.

| | **Action**   3.1.5 | Click **SkyTalk customer retention** in the breadcrumb navigation bar.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst creates a churn prediction experiment using the data previously uploaded. A lifetime value prediction experiment is also created. The analyst selects the parameter to predict and runs the experiment.

**Note**: To show how the experiments are created, see the optional “Advanced Scenario extension” at the end of this script. | | **Action**   3.1.6 | Click **SkyTalk Churn Prediction** in the AutoAI experiments section.

| | **3.2** | **Choose the best predictive model** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The analyst is automatically provided multiple candidate models, referred to as “pipelines.” On the ‘Pipeline Comparison’ chart the business analyst examines how each pipeline ranks by various model quality criteria.

For example, Pipeline 7 is the best model as determined by the ‘Area under the ROC’. Area under the ROC (receiver operating characteristic) measures the pipeline’s accuracy in differentiating useful data from noise during prediction. | | **Action**   3.2.1 | Click **Pipeline Comparison** (1) and move the cursor over the top curve in the **Area under ROC** column (2) to display the black details box.

| **Narration** | Clicking on a Pipeline provides additional details. | | **Action**   3.2.2 | Scroll down and click **Pipeline 7** in the Pipeline leaderboard.

| **Action**   3.2.3 | Click the **Model evaluation** tab.

| | **Narration** | The ‘Model evaluation’ tab shows detailed results from using the pipeline to test sample data. Out of 111 tests, Pipeline 7 predicted only 4 false positives and 6 false negatives. This translates a to a prediction accuracy of 91%.

The “Confusion matrix” shows a more granular view of the test results. | | **Action**   3.2.4 | Click the **Confusion matrix** tab.

| | **Narration** | The analyst compares Pipelines 1 & 7 to understand why Pipeline 1 is rated the best overall. | | **Action**   3.2.5 | Click the **Pipeline details** drop-down list (1) and select **Pipeline 1** (2).

| | **Action**   3.2.6 | Click the **Confusion matrix** tab.

| | **Action**   3.2.7 | Review the **Confusion matrix**. Highlight that the overall correct percentage is higher using Pipeline 1.

| | **Narration** | Pipeline 1 has a higher correct prediction percentage when all input variables are considered. After reviewing the results, the analyst selects Pipeline 1 for deployment in SkyTalk’s production environment. | | **Action**   3.2.8 | Click the x on the upper right-hand side to close the **Pipeline details** view.

| | **Action**   3.2.9 | Click **Save as** in the right-hand side of the Pipeline 1 row.

| | **Action**   3.2.10 | Select **Model** (1) and then click **Create** (2).

| | **Action**   3.2.11 | Click **SkyTalk customer retention** project in the breadcrumb navigation bar.

| | **3.3** | **Expose the model for production use** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | Promoting a pipeline makes it available for use in SkyTalk’s production space. Pipeline 1 is ready to be promoted. The ‘Retention budget’ decision can now use the churn prediction service. | | **Action**   3.3.1 | Scroll down and show the two machine learning models.

| | **Action**   3.3.2 | Display the menu on the right-hand side of the model row and click **Promote**.

| | **Narration** | In practice, the analyst would promote the churn model to the deployment environment here. For our demo it has already been promoted. | | **Action**   3.3.3 | Show the **Skytap production space** (1) option. Click **Cancel** (2) to avoid promoting the model.

| | **Narration** | The two prediction services are now ready for deployment. | | **Action**   3.3.4 | Click the **IBM Watson Studio menu** (1) and then click the **SkyTalk production space** (2).

| | **Action**   3.3.5 | Click the **Deployments** tab.

| | **Narration** | The two services have been deployed. The service endpoint URL is required to configure a machine learning provider later in the demo. The business analyst accesses and copies the first part of it.

The machine learning provider allows the ‘Retention offer’ decision service in the Cloud Pak to access the newly created pipelines when requiring the prediction results.

| | **Action**   3.3.6 | Click the **churn** service.

| | **Action**   3.3.7 | Highlight the first portion of the **endpoint URL** for use later in the demo. Only highlight from the beginning through ‘v4’, as shown in the image.

| | **Narration** | The deployment space identifier is also required to configure the machine learning provider in the Cloud Pak. | | **Action**   3.3.8 | Click the **SkyTalk production space** using the breadcrumb navigation bar.

| | **Action**   3.3.9 | Click the **Manage** (1) tab and show the **Space GUID** (2) for use later in the demo.

| **[Go to top](#top)**
4 - Calling the prediction services from the business rules
| **4.1** | **Configure customer retention decision service to use the new predictive services** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The ‘Retention budget decision’ uses the newly created churn and lifetime value predictive services to predict information in real-time. The decision service uses a machine learning provider to establishe a gateway to the predictive services.

The business analyst needs to set up a machine learning provider for the decision service in the Cloud Pak to utilize. | | **Action**   4.1.1 | Return to the **SkyTalk customer retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation menu.

| | **Action**   4.1.2 | Open the **Settings** menu.

| | **Action**   4.1.3 | Click the **Machine learning providers** tab.

| | **Action**   4.1.4 | Click **Edit** on the right-hand side of the **SkyTalk ML Provider** box.

| | **Action**   4.1.5 | Input the **API key** (1) obtained during demo preparation, the **Space ID** (2), and the **Endpoint URL** (3). Click **Save** (4).

**Note:** the Space GUID saved earlier in the demo is called the Space ID on this in interface.

| | **Narration** | Add the new corresponding predictive services to the customer lifetime value and customer churn decision services. These are the two sub decision services required for the ‘Retention budget’ decision service. To do this the analyst sets up prediction models in the Cloud Pak. | | **Action**   4.1.6 | Click **Cancel** and explain that the provider was already set.

| | **Action** 4.1.7 | Return to the **SkyTalk customer retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation.

| | **Action**   4.1.8 | Click the **SkyTalk initial retention DS** tile.

| | **Action**   4.1.9 | Click **Create**.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst now creates the first predictive model to provide the customer churn prediction. | | **Action**   4.1.9 | Select **Predictive model** (1) and name it **Customer_Churn** (2). Then click **Create** (3).

| | **4.2** | **Connect the predictive models to the deployed predictive services** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | A predictive model template is automatically created. This model needs to be connected to the churn machine learning service deployed previously in Watson Studio. | | **Action**   4.2.1 | Click **Connect**.

| | **Action**   4.2.2 | The analyst selects the **SkyTalk ML provider** created previously in the demo.

| | **Narration** | The machine learning provider establishes the link between the decision services and the machine learning environment. | | **Action**   4.2.3 | Expand the S**kyTalk churn prediction – P1 LGBM Classifier** (1) machine learning model. Then select the **churn** (2) deployment name. The prediction is now connected to the customer lifetime value.

| | **Narration** | The prediction service is now accessible. The Cloud Pak uses a preconfigured wizard to complete the connection. | | **Action**   4.2.4 | Click **Next**.

| | **Action**   4.2.5 | Click **Next**.

| | **Narration** | The input data structure is automatically created utilizing the machine learning service description. | | ***Action**   4.2.6 | Click **Run**.

| | **Narration** | The business analyst tests the connection to ensure the prediction service is responding as expected. | | **Action**   4.2.7 | Click **Next**.

| | **Narration** | The churn prediction service returns a true or false prediction and a decision accuracy evaluation. The data analyst is guided by the wizard to automatically configure the model to get the prediction results in the format required by the decision service.

To illustrate this, let’s initiate the ‘churn’ prediction service to display its output data structure. | | **Action**   4.2.8 | Click Generate from test output.

| | **Narration** | In this test the prediction is False as displayed in the left-hand side “Payload” view (2), meaning the customer is predicted to stay with SkyTalk, and there is a 58.4% chance that the prediction is correct. The prediction and the probability are now ready for use in the ‘Retention offer’ decision service. | | **Action**   4.2.9 | Click **OK** (1). **Box (2)** highlights the “F” results in the payload.

| | **Narration** | Let’s apply apply to the ‘Retention budget’ decision service. | | **Action**   4.2.10 | Click **Apply** to apply to the ‘Retention budget’ decision service.

| | **Narration** | Now let’s return to the **SkyTalk initial retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation. | | **Action**   4.2.11 | Click on **SkyTalk initial retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation menu.



| | **4.3** | **Assign the predictive model to the ‘Retention budget’ decision service** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The churn predictive service is ready to be used in the ‘Retention offer’ decision service. | | **Action**   4.3.1 | Click **Retention offer**.

| | **Narration** | The analyst can now add the churn prediction to the ‘Retention offer’ decision. | | **Action**   4.3.2 | Hover the mouse over the **Retention budget** decision box on the screen.

| | **Action**   4.3.3 | A black choice box appears over the ‘Retention budget’ decision. Click the **purple box** to **Add prediction**.



| | **Narration** | The analyst is assigns the churn predictive model to the newly created prediction. | | **Action**   4.3.4 | Select the **Prediction 8** (1) node and select the **Customer churn** (2) predictive model.

| | **Action**   4.3.5 | Review The ‘SkyTalk initial retention DS’ decision model that opens.

| | **Narration** | Using the same process, the analyst creates a second prediction for the Customer Lifetime value. The analyst then creates some data validation and data mapping rules before working on the one that will estimate the retention budget.

Let's assume this is complete and move ahead in time a see this business logic in the finalized decision service. | | **Action**   4.3.6 | Return to **SkyTalk customer retention DS** using the breadcrumb navigation menu.

| | **Action**   4.3.7 | Click SkyTalk retention DS.

**Note:** Don't use the ‘SkyTalk initial retention DS’ anymore in the scenario.

| | **Action**   4.3.8 | Click **Retention offer**.

| | **Narration** | The two predictions have been integrated into the ‘Retention offer’ decision. The analyst reviews and tests the ‘Retention budget’ rules that use these predictions. | | **Action**   4.3.9 | Click the **Retention budget** (1) box and then select the **Logic** (2) tab.



| | **Narration** | The business analyst created three business rules to test the decision service prior putting into SkyTalk’s production environment. The rules are displayed in the ‘Rules are applied in sequence’ dropdown menu.

The ‘Size importance’ rule computes a retention budget. The calculated retention budget is then adjusted by the ‘adjust with cost base’ rule.

The ‘output-default-setting’ rule returns a neutral prediction value if the machine learning service fails to respond. | | **Action**   4.3.10 | Click **size importance** to review the retention budget rule.

| | **Narration** | ‘CustomerLifetimeValue’ and ‘Churn’ are evaluated at execution, calling the predictive services with the expected input data. | | **Action**   4.3.11 | Review the **size importance** business rule.

| | **Action**   4.3.12 | **Scroll down** in the business rule to show more detail.

| | **4.4** | **Test the customer retention decision model** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | The business analyst validates the ‘Retention budget’ decision calculation and retention offers recommended by the ‘Retention offer’ decision service in test mode. | | **Action**   4.4.1 | Click the **“Run (3)”** tab (1) and select a **Test data** (2) from the list on the left-hand side.

**Note**: Do not click “Run” in the bottom right hand corner of the screenshot.

| | **Narration** | Decision outcomes are evaluated using pre-defined sample data test. Three pre-defined profiles corresponding to three customers are used for simulation. The ‘Low-value profile’ represents a customer with a very low churn risk. The expected recommendation is returned. SkyTalk sends a satisfaction survey and spends no retention budget for such customers. | | **Action**   4.4.2 | Select the **Low value profile** from the drop-down list in the left-hand side.

| | **Action**   4.4.3 | Click **Run** (1). Click **Show more* (2) after the result is displayed.

| | **Narration** | The medium profile test also returns the expected result. The churn risk is high, so a retention offer is made. The selected retention offer has a low cost since the predicted lifetime value is low. | **Narration** | | **Action**   4.4.4 | Select the **Medium value profile** (1) from the drop-down menu on the left-hand side. Then select ** Run** (2).

| | **Narration** | The last test is a customer with a high predicted lifetime value and a high churn risk. The decision service correctly recommends SkyTalk’s highest retention offer: an upgrade and an additional discount. The ‘Retention offer’ decision is working as expected. | | **Action**   4.4.5 | Select the **High value profile** (1) and then on click **Run** (2).

| | **Narration** | The ‘Retention offer’ decision service must now be versioned and deployed to the IBM Cloud to provide offer recommendations in SkyTalk’s call center application. Let’s now see how this works in the new SkyTalk Call Center application. | **[Go to top](#top)**
5 - Using the automated call center application
| **5.1** | **SGenerate a real-time retention offer that best allocates SkyTalk’s retention budget** | | :--- | :--- | | **Narration** | We’ve seen how SkyTalk used the Cloud Pak to develop an automated call center application that provides agents customer-specific retention offers in real-time.

Let’s look at a how an agent handles a call from a dissatisfied customer using the new retention offer process. | | **Action**   5.1.1 | Show the **SkyTalk – Call Center** application preview window opened during demo preparation.

**Note**: Don’t show that this application in just a preview from Application Designer since it is not in the scope of this demonstration to explain App Designer. | | **Action**   5.1.2 | Enter “Peter Carter” in the **Search Customer** field (1) and click **Search** (2).



**Note**: for the customer names to search for, Click the (?) next to the “search customer” label. | | **Narration** | Immediately a customer-specific retention offer is generated. The agent can suggest this offer to the customer in real-time. This saves time, better allocate the retention budget, and helps keep SkyTalk’s best customers with the company. | | **Action**   5.1.3 | Click the **Get offer** (1). Show that the offer automatically displays in the **application window** (2).

| **[Go to top](#top)**
Summary
Incorporating machine learning algorithms enhances even already automated operations.

Users can build complex rulesets with many variables that precisely predict target customers. There narrow the range of costs that a business can forecast to keep a desired level of attrition. Productivity and compliance are increased thanks to automation, costs are better allocated, and customer satisfaction can be increased.

Thank you for attending today’s presentation.

**Note: At the end of the demonstration**

To be able to follow the same scenario in your next demo, it is important to restore the demo to its initial state:

1. Un-deploy your ML service in your Watson Studio deployment environment to not be charged any more.
2. Return in the SkyTalk initial retention DS and remove:
- The Customer Churn predictive model
- The Customer Lifetime Value predictive model
- The 2 predictions nodes in the "Retention Offer" decision model
3. Remove the churn experiment in Watson Studio you have created if you have performed the experiment creation phase.
**[Go to top](#top)**
(Optional) 3 - Advanced extended scenario
| **3.1** | **Creating a predictive model from a data file** | | :--- | :--- | | **Note** | Depending on your demo objectives, you can just show the end resulting churn prediction and move on (3.1.6). This section shows how the business analyst creates a Watson ML Machine learning service. This is good material if you have the time and/or the audience is technical. It will take around 2-3 minutes to create the 8 pipelines for each prediction models. | | **Narration** | The business analyst starts an AutoAI experiment in Watson Studio to create a new Churn prediction, referred to as a pipeline. The AutoAI tool in Watson Studio automatically analyzes real data and generates candidate model pipelines, ranking them according to the project’s objective.

The experiment can then train, improve, and test the candidate pipelines on real data subsets. | | **Action**   3.1.5 | Click **New AutoAI experiment**.

| | **Action**   3.1.6 | **Name** the experiment "Churn prediction 2” (1) and click **Create** (2).

| | **Narration** | Now the analyst selects the customer loyalty data file and specifies the goal, predicting the likelihood a given customer is going to leave SkyTalk. | | **Action**   3.1.7 | Click **Select from project**.

| | **Action**   3.1.8 | Select the Click “**Data asset**”(1) and then select **SkyTalk customer loyalty data.xsv** file (2).

| | **Narration** | During the experiment the model automatically selects and tests various algorithms. The experiment produces a set of pipelines the business analyst reviews. Then the algorithm that best fits the project’s prediction quality criteria is selected. | | **Action**   3.1.9 | Click **Select asset** (1) and select the **CHURN** (2) column as the attribute to predict.

| | **Action**   3.1.10 | Click **Run experiment**.

**Note:** Make sure to wait until the computation is done.

| | **Narration** | Watson studio automatically suggests eight different models for the business analyst to choose from to create his prediction model.

**NOTE**: After two minutes your eight pipelines should be ready to explore. | | **Action**   3.1.11 | Return to step **3.1.7** in the main scenario script. |
**[Go to top](#top)**

Summary
Incorporating machine learning algorithms enhances even already automated operations.

Users can build complex rulesets with many variables that precisely predict target customers. There narrow the range of costs that a business can forecast to keep a desired level of attrition. Productivity and compliance are increased thanks to automation, costs are better allocated, and customer satisfaction can be increased.
